Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; simply modelled back with clypeus, prothorax and elytra marked with single, broad lines, and some detailing of mouth-parts; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside deeply incised with falcon holding flail to left and ankh sign to right; both represented rather crudely; ankh drawn in two separate elements - an oval, and a curved support beneath; longitudinally pierced; in Egyptian blue paste of pale bright tone and fine soft texture.
Curator's comments: Falcon, sometimes wearing a crown or with a flail like here, is a recurring motif for various compositions found on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Gorton included this scarab in her large group XXVIII A (Gorton 1996, 98, A142), though this type has normally only glazed composition scarabs and not Egyptian blue ones. Another Egyptian blue scarab, Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.868, was assigned to that group (Gorton 1996, 98, A144a). BM 1886,0401.1638 would fit better her group XXX A: the motifs are similar to the ones found for her group XXVIII A, but they are roughly carved in coloured pastes and especially Egyptian blue (Gorton 1996, 109-111). Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 59)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98, Type XXVIII A142) (but wrong group)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.30) (phase 3)
